But apart from such considerations, life would have lost its charm for Horace had he put himself within the trammels ‘of official service. At no time would these have been tolerable to him3 but as he advanced into middle age, the freedom of entire independence, the refreshing solitudes of the country, leisure for study and reflection, became more and more precious to him.
